title: How did an â€˜international business brokerâ€™ gain access to PM Modi for EU delegates' Kashmir trip?
content:
As 23 members of the European Parliament headed to Kashmir on October 29, speculation grew around who had arranged the visit. It was not an official delegation from the European Parliament, neither was it visiting on the invitation of the government of India.Two think tanks seem to have been the driving force behind putting together the delegation of mostly far right parliamentarians. According to Bill Newton Dunn, a member of the Liberal Democratic party in the United Kingdom, the trip had been organised by the International Institute for Non-Aligned Studies. It describes itself as a â€œthinktank for the Non-Aligned Movementâ€. But the invitations seem to have been sent out by a woman named Madi Sharma, who promised â€œa prestigious VIP meeting with the Prime Minister of India, His Excellency Narendra Modiâ€ as well as a trip to Kashmir. The invitation letter was released by another Liberal Democrat member of the European Parliament, Chris Davies, who said would not â€œjoin a PR stuntâ€. Begs the question: who is Madi Sharma, and what are her credentials to deliver on such a big promise? Because she did deliver. Here she is on the right of the PM, along with other delegation members (with the yellow scarf). pic.twitter.com/K1fNdajb0Mâ€” Sreenivasan Jain (@SreenivasanJain) October 29, 2019

Sharma claimed to be writing on behalf of the Womenâ€™s Economic and Social Think Tank. On her Twitter account, Sharma describes herself as a â€œSocial Capitalist : International Business Broker , Education Entrepreneur; Speaker.â€ Her letter, dated October 7, promised a three-day visit: â€œThe meeting with the Prime Minister is scheduled for 28th October, with a visit to Kashmir on 29th and a press conference on 30th.â€ It added that â€œflight and accommodations will be covered and are sponsored by the International Institute for Non-Aligned Studiesâ€.Non-aligned?The International Institute for Non-Aligned Studies was founded in 1980 by Dr Govind Narain Srivastava, â€œa scholar and journalistâ€ whose name is the only one listed on the instituteâ€™s website under the leadership page. Srivastava, who died in 1999, also established New Delhi Times, a newspaper that claims to have a â€œwide global readershipâ€.In its mission statement on the website, the Institute claims to have â€œprovided a platform to voice the viewpoint of billions of people of the third worldâ€. It has reportedly established a Centre for Human Rights, which covers the â€œrights of minorities and ethnic groupsâ€, â€œrights of the women and childâ€, sustainable development, â€œright to life, Democracy and Human Rightsâ€.The Institute also says it has offices in New York, Geneva and Vienna to coordinate with the United Nations, apart from regional offices in five other countries. The governing body of the Institute, the website says, consists of â€œparliamentarians, academicians, experts, diplomats and media personsâ€.Scroll.in has emailed questions to the address provided on the Institute website. When we called the number listed on the website, we were told someone from the Institute would call back. Both the Institute and the New Delhi Times share a registered address â€“ in Delhiâ€™s Safdarjung Enclave according to their websites, with a third organisation: The Srivastava Group, also established by the same Govind Narain Srivastava. According to the Srivastava Groupâ€™s website, it â€œis one of the fastest growing business houses in the country with interests in Natural resources, Clean energy, Airspace, Consulting services, Healthcare, Print Media and Publishingâ€.The Srivastava Group was recently in the news in Europe after Politico revealed that its online presence â€œoverlapsâ€ that of EPToday, a website that, â€œtargets members of the European Parliament and other policymakers with media content that is critical of Pakistan and drawn largely from a Russian media outlet known for disinformationâ€. EUvsDisinfo, an organisation funded by the European Union which examines disinformation efforts, found that EPToday, which calls itself a â€œmonthly news magazine for the European Parliamentâ€ was for the most part reproducing articles word-for-word from the Russian-owned RT.com. Another organisation, EU Disinfo Lab, a non-governmental organisation that also examines disinformation, went on to explain, in a Twitter thread, that EPToday had been pushed by the Srivastava Group and, per their websites, shares the same office as the group as well. 13/14 To summarise, EP Todayâ€™s online presence seems to have both physical (phone number, office address) and online (same servers, official registration email) links with Indian stakeholders in Brussels.â€” EU DisinfoLabğŸ‡ªğŸ‡º (@DisinfoEU) October 9, 2019

â€˜A leading womanâ€™s think tankâ€™Madi Sharma, whose think tank sent out the invitations, has bylines as the â€œEU correspondentâ€ of the New Delhi Times. Among her pieces for the newspaper are articles about everything from Kazakhstan to European trade policy. She also has a byline on the newspaper that refers to her as â€œFounder, Womenâ€™s Economic and Social Think Tank (WESTT)â€, and covers an interaction with Nayyer Hussain Bokhari, Chairman of the Senate of Pakistan, who she calls â€œone of the most important political figures from Pakistanâ€. On the Womenâ€™s Economic Forum website, she is described as the leader of the Madi Group, â€œInternational Business Broker, Education Entrepreneur; speakerâ€. The Womenâ€™s Economic and Social Think Tank is part of the Madi Group, a conglomerate of â€œinternational private and social enterprises and NGOsâ€. It claims to be a â€œa leading womenâ€™s think tank with global dimensions, focussing on the economic, environmental and social development of women. At a political level it is also lobbies to raise awareness on key issues but never for commercial gainâ€.As Newslaundry points out, Sharma runs a number of concerns, including an â€œethnic trail tour companyâ€ and Madi Magnesium, a consultancy which supports â€œSMEs, corporates, public sector organisations, NGOs and governments to overcome their challenges. Sharma also published an article on September 14 this year entitled â€œWhy demolishing Article 370 is both a victory and a challenge for Kashmiri womenâ€. It was published in EP Today.
